meanings.definition: Not adhering to a specific set of beliefs or principles.
meanings.sent1: She had a nondogmatic approach to spirituality, exploring various beliefs without committing to one.
meanings.sent2: The professor's nondogmatic teaching style encouraged students to think critically and form their own opinions.
meanings.sent3: It was refreshing to meet someone so nondogmatic in their views, open to new ideas and perspectives.
meanings.sent4: Her nondogmatic nature was like a flowing river, adapting to different beliefs and philosophies along the way.
meanings.sent5: The nondogmatic philosophy of the club allowed for diverse discussions and respectful disagreements.

meanings.definition: Not asserting opinions or beliefs as absolute truth.
meanings.sent1: He presented his ideas in a nondogmatic way, inviting others to share their perspectives.
meanings.sent2: The scientist remained nondogmatic, always willing to consider new evidence and adjust his theories.
meanings.sent3: In a world full of strong opinions, being nondogmatic can be a rare and valuable trait.
meanings.sent4: The nondogmatic approach to problem-solving was like a flexible rope, able to bend without breaking under pressure.
meanings.sent5: Her nondogmatic attitude made her a great team player, open to different viewpoints and willing to compromise.
